sp.p: I will sell my Soul to the Devill; but I will be reveng'd; May thy Daughters have the small-pox till their faces looke like the inside of a Bee-Hive; May thy Servants all have Stomachs like Cormorants, mayst thou change 'em each week and be robb'd by 'em each Month; may all thy Bankers break, thy Ventures be lost, till thou'rt as poor in thy Person as thou'rt in thy Spirit, and thy own Children deny thee— Help, Murder, Treason, Fire, Assassinates, Rebells.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He's stark mad sure?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Ay, something lies heavy upon his Conscience, he's a Strange wicked fellow:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What money was that he talkt of?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Hang him, Blasphemer, I never had a penny of him, I scorn it—
But come Child, where's my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Within Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Come along then: thou shalt certainly have her,
And such a Fortune I will make her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I expect it Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: And thou shalt have it Child—Prethee bring thy Jewells and thy Gold, and thy and what thou hast hither—Methinks I would have 'em safe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So would I, therefore I shan't trust you with 'em.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Well, prethee kiss me, thou art so like my Wife that's dead, I must needs kiss thee—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: S'death the old Fellow will ravish me I think;
Sir, your Daughter expects you.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Well, never was two faces so alike: I don't believe you're a man you Rogue, as Francisco said.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He's dismal drunk.
Here, take care of your Master:

sp.speaker: Lop
sp.l: Let me alone ye Rogues:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Go carry him into Bed:

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I will go to a Whore you Rogues:
Serv. Yes Sir,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Be sure you carry me to a Whore,
And in Her Arms I'le play,
And pass the sweet hours away,
For tho' like a Coy Virgin she lay,
I tickled her e're it was day.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What a lewd old Fellow is here?
Now for the Daughter, If she have not more
Of the Champhire in her then her Father;
The Soyles so hot for me to plant in,
Yet I might save the Priest a labour by it,
And Fornication would serve my turn as well:
If she'l be kind and save the form of Wedding,
She'l have the Advantage of a wife in Bedding.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act. Mrs. Butlers Dance.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I Never was so Toung-worried in my Life,
Thou art more troublesome then a Woman-Wit
And altogether as Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To see how Pride corrupts manners, rather then
Confess your Frailty, you'l be rude; But do stifle
Your passion till it choak you, do—till like a
Secret in a Fool it itches, so to be reveal'd you
May scratch your self to death for vexation.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Sweet Soul, how it fancies it self; I'le call for a
Cestern of water, where like Amorous Narcissus
It shall Court the shadow of its own Beauties.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If you'l Act Diana, I may see some of your Ladyships:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Wou'd I were any thing but what I am;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'le make worse of you presently if yon please:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Art thon a Man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You had best try:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: No, thou hast the Appearance of many, but not the Soul
Of one, thou art a Compound of all Nations, without
The perfections of any; thou art neither well-
Fashion'd, Well-made, nor well-bred, but a most
Compleat bungle of Nature; Thou hast the
Insolence of a Spaniard, the heavyness of a
Dutch-Man, the haughtiness of a German, the dullness of
An Irish-Man, and the Impudence of an English-Man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am glad on't with all my heart, for thou hast
All the Pride of an Italian, the Gayety of a
French-woman, the management of a Venetian,
And the Spirit of a Welsh-woman.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I'le stay no longer;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: You will not force me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, but I'le keep you here

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: And I shan't go,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: No:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No—you shan't, you shan't, faith; not
That I am fond of your Company, but since I
Have no other, I will not be left alone:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You had as good, for I'le not loose another word on thee:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So much the better; when the Thunder's expell'd
The Sky may grow clear, and I like a Landskip
better then a Storm.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Your Importunity's intollerable.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I have my Ends—and I'le be as diligent
In perplexing thee as I would in my attendance
On a great Man, who to ease himself of an
Assiduous Suiter, bestows something on him to
Keep him out of the way, and so is tyred into a kindness.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I could find in my heart to marry thee to be rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Faith do, 'tis as good a Receipt for Separation,
As borrowing Money is to break Friendship;
'Tis a Trade among the Grandees all over
Europe, A man of Quality would no more
Be seen with his Wife after he has treated her
Relations and secur'd her Portion, then a Mistriss
Would admit of the Visits of her Cully when she
had spent his Estate, or a Gamester endure
The Conversation of his Buble after he had won all.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: How proud you are of these Villanies and
With what pleasure you relate 'em:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Therefore I would have the women be wiser and
Take the Man they like without that sure
Physiek of Matrimony, it kecks in the stomach,
And works in each Faculty, and purges out the
Very desire we Wed for: Love's like a Bottle
When freely propos'd, to depart when you
Please, or as long as you please, but when once
Is Constrain'd it Curdles i'th Blood, it palls every
Tale; Each Glass is a Potion, and poisons the
Kind Conversation you met for.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: What can'st thou see in that impudent face
Of thine, to imagine any she-thing would trust
Thee without substantial Security?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Faith nothing, but that Impudence you speak of:
Assurances is half in half with a woman.
If we're modest when we woo you, you're
Afraid we'le be bashfull when we have you.
If the Spirit be meek, you Conjecture the Flesh
Must be feeble, and a modest Lawyer can
Never have good Practice.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Nor an Impudent one a good Reputation, he
May baffle a Cause, but never maintain one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, you're conceited;

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I am sorry I invade your Property:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your Sex is all Vanity:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: And yours all deceit, 'tis the practice of
Your Souls to seduce us into Faith, you're
Never well but when you're belov'd, nor easy
When you are so, Change is your delight,
And Constancy your Scandall; you Curse
Every man that's falser then your selves,
And are Potent in nothing but perjury.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well I'le have done for the present, and like
An Ingenious Preacher leave off whilst my
Sermon is hot in your memory, and not
Doze your Attention with dwelling too long on
The Subject, therefore hoping you may edify by
My Present Doctrine, I'le finish my text at
Our next meeting—Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: With all my heart:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You'l Cry when I'm gone:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: 'Twill be for fear of your return then:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, I can have the Liberty of Serenading,
And expect not to sleep when I wake.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Wou'd thou wert gone once.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am departing:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Peace be with you:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will so maul thee when I have thee.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: No, I shall sleep then I suppose without Serenading:

sp.speaker: Ant▪
sp.l: May all thy thoughts thy Soul towards mans Flesh bend.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: And may you prove as good as you pretend,
Well, I do like this Fellow,
And Love him I'm afraid,
But I am sensible he has as good thoughts of me:
What Fools are women to hide their Inclination,
When they are satisfyed the man's their own:
But 'tis a Policy our Mothers teach us
Persuading 'twill inflame the Lover more,
When Every Tedious hour delays our bliss,
And makes us keep what most we wish were his.

div.head: SCENE. II.
div.stage: The Backside of the City, near a Church.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Either we have out-staid our time,
Or Darkness Creeps too hastily upon us,
Canst tell the hour, Sancho?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: It should be towards supper-time by the
Wambling Chimes of my Carkass, pox of this Love,
It starves the whole Family, and because your
Honour can dyet with Camelions, you
Think in manners we ought not to fare better.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Art thou not asham'd of thy Gluttony?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No, but I am of my Abstinence, this is fasting
Without doing Heaven any service; never
Did Love Monopolize like yours: Starving
Honour I have heard of, but this Effeminate
Punctilio is a disgrace to your Sex:
Nothing but sighing, and thinking, and walking
Discontentedly in Fields, as if the blood of a
Murder lay on your Conscience.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Prethee hold thy idle Tongue:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Would I had wherewithall to divert it otherways;
I am indebted to my stomach 3 meals, and can't
Get one to be bayl for me, good Sir think
Upon some means to pay something down
To stop his mouth a little, for I have Confess'd
A Judgment to hunger, and famine will
Serve an Execution on me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If thou mindst thy wife when thou hast one,
As much as thou dost thy belly, she'l have a good time on't

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I'm sure If I don't mind that, she'l have an Ill
Time on't; you know no body now adays take
Houses with bare walls, wenscoat me well with
Beef, and it may recommend me to a good Tenent.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: It must be he, for this is the time and place we were directed to observe:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Strikes not this nine, Sancho?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes sure it does:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I'm right in my Appointment then.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: May I be so in mine, If this fail,
we must all fall on him

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ha! art hurt Sancho▪

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Not that I know of;

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Assist thy Master then:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Against any thing but the Devill:

sp.speaker: 1 Bra.
sp.l: Fall on:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Oh villains, this is Carlos's work:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: They give ground Sir.

div.stage: Enter Carlos and Guzman as the Bravo's are retiring, and Joyns with 'em.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Oh Cowardly Dogs! but think not Silvio thou shalt escape me:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: 'Tis like thee base and treacherous Carlos.

div.stage: As Silvio and Sancto give ground Enter Antonio and Joyns 'Em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha giving ground! for the weaker side, like a true Champion.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: So I am satisfyed.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: There's a rising-blow for you:

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Dogs—

div.stage: At last Carlos falls and the Bravos all run.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Help, murder, murder:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha! what noyse is this, and just before my door?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who are you Sir, and how is it with you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am a Stranger Sir; but slightly hurt I think;
I have only time to thank your Generosity; If
There's no murder done I'le find you out, and
Study to return this happy rescue:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'le wait you till you're out of danger.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: By no means Sir, you are not known, and may
Be safe, I am; this mischief has been
hatching too some time; therefore I
Beg you would Enquire no more; If
I do well, I certainly will seek you,
If not I'le ever love your memory.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Help Pedro; Sphorso, I shall bleed to Death:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha! Is not that my Sons voice? Lights there:
Murder, oh my Child, Lights, Rogues, murder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shift for your self then; for
The hounds are near us.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sancho

sp.speaker: San▪
sp.l: Your shaddow Sir:

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: I'm maul'd like a forlorn hope:

sp.speaker: Carl,
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Don Carlos l

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Who's that Guzman? art thou hurt too?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Like Master, like man, at present, I am
Stuck as if I were to be Larded:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What are you? and why this out-cry?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: I'm in Labour Sir, and want to be delivered.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Guzman—my Son too wounded and on the
Earth; oh! speak, who did it? what,
Not a word—oh! speak, how is it with thee?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: My Soul is like a Lamp on its departing,
My Blood the oyl that fed it is quite spent,
And nature Struggles for its last pale glimps.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Oh horrid villany, get Doctors, Slaves, and Surgions,
Summon a College of Pulse-fumblers, and
Lint-Scrapers, propose rewards to shew
Their utmost Art; sly slaves—in gently, villains,
Gently with him, look to your Fellow-servant.

sp.speaker: 1 Servant.
sp.l: Alas poor Guzman.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: None of your pitty, but lend me your help,
They have miss'd my heart, I think, and that's all,
I am slash'd like grill'd mutton; oh for some
Conger-Eels to stop these Leapings; Softly Rogues,
Softly, I shall come to my Journeys end soon Enough.

div.stage: A noise within of pursue this way.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What Shall we do? we run mazes sure and
Come to the End where we begun; ha! here's a
Garden-wall; by your leave who ever you
belong to, If he be noble he will protect me:
Follow me Sancho.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I warrant you Sir, I have been
Us'd to rob orchards—what's the matter now?
I cannot mount it, and have hopt over higher
in my time; I believe the Devill's at my arse,
And thinking I am Climbing towards Heav'n,
Tugg's me back as if I were out of my way:
Up Gundy or be stuck with Soledo's,
Till thou lookst like a Porcupine and shoots
Thy Quills Backwards—

div.head: SCENE. III.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Surely thou wilt be late:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Oh fear not, Madam, your true Lover will
Out-wait an Angler, and thinks not his
Time ill-spent, If he catches a fish at last,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No more delays, but hast:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I'le be with him in less then a tickling time.

div.stage: As she's going off Sancho runs against her, and they both fall.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Murther, Theeves, Theeves:

div.stage: Dorothea Shreiks, and as she's running off is met by Silvio who Catches her in his arms.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Dorothea!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Silvio!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The same and thine for ever;

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Sancho, what art thou? a mole, hast got no eyes?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No, but I want the strength of one to heave this
Earth up—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How got you In?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Pursu'd by villains I leapt the wall
For Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: As I was waiting for my guide to approach thee,
Four Bravo's set on me, one fir'd at me, but mist;
Streight they all came on me, I had the good fortune to
Receive 'em well; nay they were giving ground:
When Carlos Roar'd, think not thou shalt escape,
And seconded their attempt.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.l: Oh Heav'ns!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My advantage quickly lessen'd, and I had perish'd
But for the kind relief of one I knew not, I think
some fell; who with their Crys allarm'd the neighbour-hood;
I got in here hoping to miss their fury,
And chance has guided me to what I long'd for:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Let us retire and think upon some means how
To Secure thee, Oh my Silvio, 'tis what I dreaded:
But by my Love I will partake thy fate
Let Stars be as malicious as they please.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sure all must be propitious in the End,
Or Heaven's Partiall to the most deserving.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Oh I shake!
My Soul as if it gave me warning sickens,
And Sighs out, we must never meet again.

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.l: Let's never part then, and defy the Omen;
Thus fortify'd by Love we'le dare the foe,
Till our ill Stars grow weary of the Siege,
Or at the general Assault we'le stand
When their dire Influence is ready drawn,
'Gainst the vast breach of all our miseries,
And where Oppression's thickest fall together.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, let us Study how to live together:
I have reveal'd the secret to my Father,
All thoughts of Reconcilement with your Rivall
Are quite discarded; he seems enclin'd to
What I have propos'd—nay, I've more to tell
Thee; If the description I have heard don't Err,
Thou hast a Brother here, one Don Antonio, Son
To Don Michael Frederick of Peru.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.l: Go in, I'le tell thee all:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I wait it with Impatience:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Oh Silvio, to loose thee now,
When all my hopes were in such perfect health,
They seem'd insur'd against all Accidents,
'Tis like a Chymist whose unwearied Toyle
With eager diligence long time had search'd,
Through every curiosity of Nature,
To bring his mighty project to perfection;
And when the wish'd for Art he had attain'd,
Dyed in its finishing Operation: away
Farmosa, stay you here, If any disturbance
Should approach our Walls, give notice of it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I suppose I must come up
With the baggage, and may halt with your Ladyship:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: A likely fellow this, how long have you lived with your Master, friend?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Ever since he has lived with me, he never
Forsook me, nor will I ever discharge him.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: A pleasant Fellow, what are you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: His Portmanteau, I carry his Equipage:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I mean, what Country-man are you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A Resident of chance:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A Courtier, a Gam'ster, a Pimp, a Vallet,
Or any thing that all Countries, Religions, or
Customs are alike to:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: A Savoury Fellow, and rellishes of Wit▪
Are all women too as well as Countrys,
Religions, and Customs, alike to you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: All of this side fifty:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Then there's hopes for me, for I want a year
On't: If I could marry this Rogue and redeem
My Virginity now, 'twould do well; I have a
Pretty good sum of money which I have scrap'd
Together in Service; and mine is not the first
Crack'd Reputation has been put off that way:
Besides that Villain Guzman grows weary
Of me, and will never be brought to buy that
Out-right which he has had the use of so
Often for nothing.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I'le strike in with this Autumn, this latter
Season if I can; for they say she has made
Good use of her time, and has been highly
Presented by her Mistrisses Suiters, what tho' she be somewhat
Antient I shall break her heart the sooner, I'le
Enamour her first with my Graces, and then
My Person will appear more lovely.
Sweet Nimph, if that you are at Leisure
To hear a Swains misfortune,
You of my heart have made a seizure,
And yours I do Importune:
Oh let it, let it not be said,
A Man of Comely feature
Should be slighted by a scornfull Maid,
So become a wretched Creature.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: As I hope to be honest his Organ is delicious,
He shall hear the Excellence of mine:
Signior, you shall not find me so hard-hearted
To scorn the offers of a Love so true,
But since a flame so Generous you've started,
Take me, and I'le take you;
All I am Mistriss of I give
My heart's fully resign'd
A blushing Virgin then receive
And prethee work me to thy mind.

sp.speaker: Saa.
sp.l: Good, she comes—Most admirably perform'd—
Let me salute the Orifice of your Melody:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Far short of yours Sir, pray be ingenious, and
Tell me in what Climate you stole this great
Accomplishment?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: In England.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Were you born there?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Stark naked:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Waggish Brittain:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Let me once more adore that heav'nly voice:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Beshrew me but your Endearments are very
Warm: If a virgin should be good-natur'd
And like you, you Could not be constant.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: As pride to Authority, or first Love to its appointments.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: If I should throw my self away upon thee,
Would you really, truly, sincerely, and faithfully
Serve me?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Zealously: I'le be fonder of thee then the
Spirituall Court of an Ill neighbour.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: We'l go in and talk more on't.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Agreed and make more on't too if I can:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: If he has heard any thing of me, and Guzman,
I shall be puzled for a denyall—I'm resolv'd;
I'le forswear it and protest my honesty and
Innocency, nay, I have a good mentall
Reservation for it:
For tho' by Guzman's Love I was betray'd,
I'le swear for thee I am a Reall Maid.

div.head: SCENE IV.
A Hall.
div.stage: Enter Biancho, Neice, and women, and Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nay prithee Child:

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Away, and give me Liberty to vent my Griefs,
I know you not, you are all my Enemies;
Why do ye preach up patience for my woes,
Yet Bar the Remedy that would procure it?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Nei.
sp.l: Why she has heard of Carlos's misfortune,
And nothing can appease her:

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why Biancha, thou shalt see Don Carlos,
I'le carry thee to him:

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: No, 'tis too late:

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He's hurt, but not destroy'd, he will recover:

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: 'Tis Equally to me, Dye or Revive,
If he recovers, Dorothea has him,
If not I cannot;
For should I follow him to the other world,
And he retains the Passion which he fell for;
I in Elizium shall neglected pass.
The wretched pitty of each happy pair.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No, 'twill be better, the match is broke,
Thy Rivall loves another, and when he's sensible
What you endure, I'm sure his Soul will
Readily Embrace you.

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: What, must I tell him that I Love him then?
No, let my feaver dry me first to Ashes,
If Heaven deprives me of my Virgin-Love:
Oh! mark me with its figure on my Soul,
That by the Token you may know hereafter
What here I wanted, and present him there.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Wilt thou not hear me?

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: You 〈◊〉 not me when I entreated harden:
Oh heart-hard Stubborn heart break or forget
Thy Passion.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Dost thou desire to see thy Father dead?

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Father, what Father?—Fathers love their Children,
Indulge their tender tempers, fond their humours,
And when they are just, comply with their desires;
Mine unregarded, heard me sue and sigh,
Nay, like a common beggar past me by,
As if entreating were a Trade I practic'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Neice, do thou solicit for me, friends all
I beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Well 'twon't be long e're I shall go abroad,
And walk in Paradice with my dear Love;
A Terras-walk we'le have above the rest,
Which shall be sprinkled o're each morn with Pearl,
And bruised by Rowling Stones of Diamonds,
Drawn by two Angells, Lovely as himself,
Whilst wondring Saints shall listen to our Songs
And learn from us how to be truly happy.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Heav'n guard your Sences:

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Heav'n! I have a Song of Heav'n▪
Come, come, ye Inhabitants of Heaven▪
Conduct me to my Love,
Where by the Gods we may be given,
Where nothing can our Joys remove:
I mount, I fly, my Rosy Wings
Expand and Cut the yielding Air,
Each little Cherubin my Welcome Sings,
And Fathers cannot hurt us there.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Follow her all, Come Neice—

sp.speaker: Neice.
sp.l: So this I hope will do
'Twas rarely Acted,
If she can keep it up the Man's her own,
Oh Children bred by Nature to deceiving,
And Silly Parents cheated by beleiving;
When I have any, if a Man will take me,
As 'twould be hard if they should all forsake me:
Girles, I especially would watch their waters,
For Mothers by themselves may guess their Daughters.

div.stage: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Discovers Don Carlos on a Couch, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.l: MY Feavour lessens, and I gather strength,
The blood that fed the follys of my Love
Is fled through every wound its Rage occasion'd,
And prudent Iudgment Reassumes her seat;
The Powers are Just, for I did Ill
To seek Redress by such vile Practices:
Oh Biancha! I have done thee wrong,
Neglected what my Stars seem'd to enjoyne,
And they have prov'd they hate my stubborn choice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good morrow Boy, how is't?
Didst thou rest well? dost thou continue, temperate?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I hope I shall do well,
Nature it's wonted measure seems to affect,
And all my faculties return to order.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well, hast thou consider'd child,
What I propos'd about Biancha's Love;
Pox o'this Dorothea and her Father,
They never I believe, either of 'em lik'd us;
Besides, t'will be such a Revenge to slight her
And marry the other,—She'l look as melancholly
As a Discarded Statesman, and out-Fret a
Court-beauty for her Taylors disappointment at a Ball.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sir I have weigh'd, and wholly resign my
Self to your disposall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well said Boy, I will make such a man of thee,
Thou shalt out-shine a Country Squire on the
Sabbath, Live higher then a whore in her first
Month; And out-strut a Citty-Colonell at the
Head of his Regiment: nay we'le have Justice
From old Lopez too.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir Don Pedro is below, and desires to
Speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ads me, he sent to me, and desir'd me to stay
At home, 'tis thy Father in Law that must be,

sp.speaker: Carlos;
sp.l: well such things I will do for thee—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Do what you please, all shall be easy to me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Well, thou art the best Boy; thy obedience is so
Inducing, Charming and Obliging, as I hope
To live, I am afraid I shall dye a year sooner
then I intended, to make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: I willingly would go into the Garden, the
Air, Sir, may refresh me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Wait on him to the Garden, I'le be with thee presently.
Well things are brought about rarely,
Now will he have a swinging fortune with
Biancha:
And after her Fathers Death all his Estate.
He shall have all mine too when I'm dead,
I will take her Portion and settle so much
per annum, and Live upon him into the Bargain;
I'le not part with a free penny, till I cann't help it.
When Parents once upon their Children Live,
Tho' all they have we gave 'em, yet they greive;
Therefore to keep mine still at my Command,
I'l leave the world before I part with Land.

div.stage: Scene discov'rs Guzman in a Chair. A Chirurgeon by him, and a Table with Gally-Pots, Vrine-Violls, &c.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Well Sir, and how long must I endure your probings and your Cullices?

sp.speaker: Chirurg.
sp.l: A week, if you keep a good Dyet, will set you Right again.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Why there he is, a good Dyet, that is, eat nothing▪
Suppose I keep an ill Dyet, and eat, will a
Fortnight cure me?

sp.speaker: Chirurg.
sp.l: A fortnight! by'r Lady, it may cost you your Life for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Nay, for ought thou know'st, I may dye to night
Of a Quinzey.

sp.speaker: Chirurg.
sp.l: Why, so you may Sir.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Yes, I thought so; Suppose
I have a mind to let blood:

sp.speaker: Chirurg.
sp.l: You have lost enough already one would think,
I see no occasion for that.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Ay! but there may be for ought thou knowst:
What a wretch am I order'd to look after me?
Because I am a Servant I must have no other
To take care of me; my Master has the head of
The Doctors and Chyrurgeons, and I must be
Manag'd by their Glister-Carrier.

sp.speaker: Chirurg.
sp.l: You are dispos'd to be merry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Very well, because I don't like this Rascall,
I am dispos'd to be merry; hark ye you
Serringe-Bobber,—disposeme to be merry you
Had best, or I'le depose you from your Quack-Salving—
I would drink a Glass of Sack.

sp.speaker: Chirurg.
sp.l: You may do what you please, but it may do you harm.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Ay, for ought thou knowst—why you Dog,
Suppose I have a mind to a wench.

sp.speaker: Chirurg.
sp.l: A wench!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Ay a Wench, oh 'tis a kind Decoction, meet and
Proper for the Body of a man, operating
Simpathetically towards the healing of the Inwards.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: A Woman will kill you Sir.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: I don't mean to work so hard Sir, to debauch once
a Month is a Cordial they say.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Why, Nature is so Exhausted, it would not supply
You if you had really a desire for one,
Your Spirits are wasted.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Why you dog, d'ye take me for a boys
Pot-Gun, without any pith in my back.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here's a Young woman would speak with Guzman.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: A young Woman, bring her in.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: If she be a young woman keep her out.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Hark you Diaculum-Dauber, let her come in.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: She shall not come in.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Shan't she, Urinall-peeper.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Sirrah, bring her up:

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Sirrah, keep her down.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Bring her up, or I'le Murder thee.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Bring her up, and I'le poison thee.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: I will bomb thee with thy own Gally- Pots then.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: To try Experiments upon
You with your own Slops and Salves;—
There's a Bowlus for you, there's a Potion,
There's a Glyster, there's a Julip,
There's an Oyntment.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Help, Murder.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Take 3 Spoonfulls fasting of this, and sweat after this;
And sleep after this; hang your self at the last, and
Be dam'd after all.

div.head: Scene Changes to Don Francisco's Garden.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Indeed this goodness far exceeds my thoughts,
I could not hope such mercy from your wrongs;
But as you Copyed Heav'n in suffering 'em,
You seem still more Divine in your Forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: The Frailties of my passion were too great
For me to hide
I would have smother'd it and kept it down
In the dark Duugeon of forgetfullness,
But oh! The Barrs of Virgin-Decency
Were all too weak to bind the Prisoner in,
Like strugling winds in hollow Caverns pent,
It burst my feeble Breast, and Sigh'd its way out.
Then, as the Clouds by Grumbling, Thunder forc't,
In showers it gush'd from my o're-swelling Orbs.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: They have at length moisten'd this stubborn Clay,
And made it plyable to thy desires; work me
Like Yielding wax, I'le fashion with thy will,
And figure with the wishes of thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Oh happy Change!
Heav'n cannot more rejoice when Sinners sigh,
Than I for thy Conversion.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Nor can a Soul convinc'd of long liv'd Errors,
Embrace the blessed Truth with more delight,
Then I my Dear Biancha.
Thus let me shew my humble Penitence,
Here let me languish for my past Offence,
And take forgiveness at my Alters Feet.

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Thus the kind Oracle enjoyns thy Penance,
Love her who has thy tedious absence mourn'd;
Nor cease, till by Biancha thou art scorn'd.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Yet nearer, nearer yet.

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Lock me within thee,

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Oh! Mercy—

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: Love.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Goodness on Goodness,
There is but one that's just in thy whole Sex,
And thou art She.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Joy, Joy, Eternal Joy, rise my blessings,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: My Comforts.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Sir, for what's past—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No Excuses, she's thine, and thou art hers;
What's past be forgotten, and what's to come
Keep to your selves.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I long to see them one, ah! Carlos, Carlos, that I were in a Condition to take thy place that Night; but no matter, I'll tell thee how I did at thy Age, and if thou can'st out-fling thy Daddy a Barr's length, much good do thy Spouze with it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I warrant you Brother, she'll match him, or she's a Bastard by the Mother's side; but Brother—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Brother—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You stand to what we've agreed on.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Do I hope to be a Grand-father—to see a—chopping Rogue come out of thy Parcely-Bed, and hear it cry Granny, Daddy.—If thou dost not get her with Child in a Month, by the Champion of Spain I'll do't my self.
sp.l: Ads! precious, I could so—Go, get you in you
Little Rogue you, or I shall marry thee my—
Self, and put his nose out of Joynt. Go, go.
Lord I am so wanton,
My Blood's as warm as
Five and twenty Brother. How do you feel your self?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am at frozen Sixty Brother, Nature has no such Extasies in my Veins.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why truly, I think mine is but a flash,
Yet we have been Brother—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ay! We have have been Brother—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A Pox o' this Inclination without Power,
But the Comfort is, tho young Rogues will be old
Like us, and love to talk on't when they are
Past the Action.—But come, let us follow our
Intentions, and go where we resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Well, this Boy and this Baggage puts me so in mind
Of the Night I got her in—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Well, think no more on't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ah Brother!
Old Souldiers, their past Actions, love to own.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ah Brother!
And often Brag of more then has been done.

div.head: Scene changes to Don Lopez his House.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Then Carlos is recover'd?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thanks to my Stars, I hear so.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Well, I have sent to this Antonio to come to me to Night, I find I am a Fool, and ask you pardon for all I have said of Silvio.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I rejoyce in your Repentance.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: But what's become of Silvio?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why, he's safe, under the care of Signior Octavio, a neighbouring Merchant, an Ancient Friend of his Fathers; But I have sent to him concerning Carlos's recovery, and he will come to night; I have told my Father he's the Brother of your Lover, and he approves of his Amour.—but here he comes, Ill tell you more anon.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Well Children, have you heard any more concerning Carlos?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nothing but that he's forward on his Recovery,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Well, and when did you see Antonio?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Not since yesterday.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I think I have provided well for you, you young Baggage;
You'll taste man earlier by three years then your Mother, take heed
you don't surfeit Filly.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Oh! Preach that to the Men, they are apt to be soonest cloy'd.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Well Dory, I have consider'd concerning this Silvio; If it be prov'd Adtonio and he are Brothers, take thy choice, I'll not Interrupt thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I humbly thank you Sir, and hope he'll prove he merits me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, Supper waits.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Ads me, come Girls, come, my Appetite's provoking.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Sister bear up.
Thou'lt have thy man near doubt, and so shall I,
'Twere hard for our first Longings we should dye.

div.head: Scene the Street.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I have told you all the Progress of my Love,
And ever must acknowledge your Assistance,
The Hazards I have vanquish'd, give me hopes
I may at last possess what I have toil'd for;
I only want to find my Brother out;
Likewise, I beg you'd go with me this Night
To satisfie Don Lopez what I am.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You may be sure, all I can serve you in is full as welcom to my Soul, as to your own.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I have sufficient reason to believe it;
And what you have told me of Don Carlos,
Relating to the Daughter of Don Pedro,
Together with his bless'd recovery,
Creates in me a double Joy.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: And view, a Slave impatient of thy Sight;
Behold a Wretch by thee undone,
Whose Heart is all thy own.
Oh! Guide him in this starless Night,
And let thy Eyes create new Light.

div.stage: Enter a Spanish Count with Musick, Serenaders, &c.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Some Serenading Gallants to my Mistress,
If they stay long I shall be rude to 'em.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let us observe 'em, I may chance to know 'em.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: May the Eyes of my Mistress everlastingly flourish
And my constant Affection I hope they will nourish;
For if my Amour Dorothea don't cherish,
By the Lord I am likely, most likely to perish.
sp.p: God this don't do I believe, I am whorse, and she don't hear my Musick.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Sir, I have some Affairs in this Family; which oblige me to wait here, and it would conduce much to my designs if you would please to retire.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sir, I have some Affairs in this Family, which oblige me to wait here, and it would conduce much to my designs if you would go about your business.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am about it Sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: So I am about mine Sir, may the Eyes of my Mistress—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Heark ye Sir, If you will not quit your post,
I must endeavour to force you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Force me, draw Fidlers.

div.stage: [Silvio draws, and the Merchant, and beat 'em off crying Murder.

div.head: Scene changes to a Garden Wall.
div.stage: Enter Lopez with a Torch, and his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What cry of Murder's this?
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Of whence▪

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Of England, and going to my Lodging was set upon by Villains, If you have Honour give me your Protection.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Question not what I have, but follow me.

div.head: Scene changes to the inside of a Garden.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Here, step into that Arbor, I'll go and see if my Servants be remov'd, that you may be safe; I'll be with you presently, for if the Corrigedore be rais'd—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: By Heaven! this is the Father of my Love,
What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Well; we Confidents have a sad time on't, up at all hours, and ready upon all Occasions; And for Lying no People come near us. I fent Antonio the key of the Garden, and this is the time he was order'd to be in the Arbor, I think I see him, hist▪ Sir, my Mistress stays for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What shall I say, by Heaven this is some Appointment with a Rival, Oh false Dorothea!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Nay, come—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will have Patience to see the end of this.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Lord 'tis very dark! well, it's a pleasant time for Lovers, if I had a Gallant I should love the dark excessively.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What does the old Hagg mean?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: If a man had a mind of ravish me in the dark,
I swear, I believe I should not dare to cry out.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Come lead me to your Mistress

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Well, you have the softest hand that ever I felt.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Here's something to soften thine.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: This was not the thing I meant; He's so dull I cannot perswade him to be rude.—this Climate has such a heavy Influence on man in England, now the Maids are often their Mistresses Tasters; Come then, since you are so stupid—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Oh! Women, Women, Why do men believe 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This Garden is so large, and 'tis so dark, I scarce can grope this Arbour out. Oh! for my Mistress on a soft bed of Roses, yielding as I am, with transported Sighs, then blubbering for the Joy her Love had lost—with one hand pushing me, the other griping, till by repeated bliss her griefs forget, and she rejoyces in the flame she dreaded. Oh! here's the Arbor, would my Guide would come.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Come Sir, all's clear, and I'll preserve you till the search is over, and then take care for your escape.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Escape, the Devil, what can this mean.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nay, Come Sir, come.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I dare not disobey, but what the Event will be, Fortune knows.

div.head: Scene changes to Farmosa's Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Stay here till I see if the old man be safe, and Ill conduct you to my Lady speedily.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Tis so, her fickle Soul is fond of some new Face;
As Carlos was for me scorn'd and neglected,
So am I now for this; yet I shall see this faithless
Fair Persuader, that led my Soul away towards promis'd
Joys, and now 'tis plung'd in love, laughs at its
Sufferings.
Oh Woman! Woman! thou Primitive Seducer,
That with the Serpent club'd for our Damnation:
Man was forewarn'd, and could have stood his Guile,
But thou, the greater Fiend, not being suspected,
Finish'd what Satan but imperfect drew.

div.stage: Sancho creeps from under the Bed.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: I am almost smother'd, and so stung by Vermin, that if I had a Glass I might fancy I had the Small-Pox; the Fleas have danc'd backwards and forwards o'r me this three hours, that I am gawl'd as if a Nest of Aunts had travail'd over me with their hoard for Winter.
Heark! the Door opens.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Stay here one Minute, and I'll fetch a Light.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What have we now—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What will become of me, I know not, I must put a good Face upon the matter, and pretend I only came to see what house his Daughter kept.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This surely is my Rival; what are you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: S'death, is the House haunted, what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thou art a villain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou lyest, be a good Angel or a bad.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I'll feel what you are.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll keep thee at Arms length if I can.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: So, here's murder going forward, would I coud get under the bed to my leap Frogs again.
sp.stage: [They push at one another, and at last Antonio falls over Sancho a top on him.]
sp.p: Help! Murder! Oh! I quake for fear of a chance thrust in my bowels; murder, help, murder.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Lye still, or thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Ah! what's here, three men, thieves, give me my Sword, fetch up my great Guns, help, thieves there, thieves.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: For Heavens sake what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Now I shall see the Face which has undone me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Silvio.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes Madam, unexpected.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Antonio, what brothers fighting!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Antonio!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Silvio! what Stars set us at odds?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: They have lost their aim, I hope thou art not hurt, forgive me Madam; Oh my brother! My Soul's divided so 'twixt Love and Frindship, I know not which to serve.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I miss no Love you e're can shew to him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nor I no Friendship he bestows on you. Nay, come into the Lump, and let's all four unite into one Soul; where hast thou been? but more of that hereafter; but what is he, we stumbled on?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Your faithful Friend and Slave Sancho.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sancho! How cam'st thou hither?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I was lock'd in by my Lady Farmoza, I came on the same design your honour did, only my Love was plac'd on a lower object.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Does thy heart lean that way?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Faith Sir I should be loath to part the Family,
I have promis'd her for Spouze,
sp.p: Therefore I beg we may live with you still; make her your housekeeper, and me your valet, though I'm preferr'd, I am not grown proud Sir,
sp.l: But is this your honours Brother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: At your Service Sir.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: My respects to you Sir, shall prove how much I honour my Masters Relations.

div.stage: Enter Lopez with a Gun and Servants.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Stand clear, make room, or I fire on all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What my dear Father, cock't against your Daughters.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and this his Brother, of whom my Sister fully has inorm'd you, Lop. his Brother, Sil. yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: How got they in?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sir, you conducted me hither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And this key, by your Daughters Appointment, gave me admittance.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Besure you oyl the wards well, and keep 'em from Rusting. But Son in Law, is this really your Brother?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The very Brother I told you I was in search of, how we have mist each other here, I know not, but we are met at last, nor shall the world part us; my Fathers Death—I suppose this Lady has given you a full Account of—my Travels are too tedious for the present, we'll talk of 'em hereafter, the four thousand Crowns my Father left, I freely deliver to you, and only contrive some way that I may purchase this man's meat, and I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Sir, I have a thousand Crowns more in Don Octavio's hands, which shall be put to what my Brother speaks of, and be divided equally betwixt us, if you think them Recommendations sufficient to your Daughters Love, we are happy; if not, we must submit, and curse the Scantiness of our Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Sir, you speak worthily: and had ye no fortunes? So well I like your Principles, I should esteem them Estates of themselves. The morning comes fast upon us, the transactions of this night we'll deferr till a more Leisure time; here, take my Daughters, and use 'em as their behaviour deserves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If mine have a Conscience, and will be contented with what I have, I shall think nothing too much for her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I expect no voluntiers, be just to your Family Duties, that's all I shall look for.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I run upon tick Cuckold me—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Even Reckonings you know, make long Friends, be prudent, for as you use me at first, I shall expect hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Well, do you think you'r match'd—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll tell you after the first night Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Now Dorothea, now our fears are ended;
How shall we recompence our Sufferings,
But by excess of Joys.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Spare my blushes, and take me to your self.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Sir, here's Don Octavio below enquires for Don Silvio.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Entreat him to appear, 'tis my Appointed Guardian, by my Father whilst I inhabit here.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I desire his presence.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Silvio, I joy to see you safe,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You see me happier then e're I thought for.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Signior Octavio, you'r an earlier riser—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Indeed I have not been in Bed this night,
My Soul's disorder'd for Don Silvio's safety
Has interrupted all my usual customs;
But since I see him well, I find my self so.
And Signior Lopez, if you think him worthy,
As I am sensibly your Daughter does; his family
Is noble, and his Fortune equal to—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sir, we are satisfied already.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Brother pray be acquainted with my friend.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: It this Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The same, and in my Brothers interest much obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Sir, I believe the Inhabitants of Sevill have been all upon the Ramble to night, for here's Don Francisco, Don Pedro, Don Carlos, and the Lord knows who below.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Why, they'r welcome, bring'em up, and we'll be friends with all; it shan't be said on such a day, I have emnity with any, if Franciso is to be reconciled, I'll refuse no Articles, he shall propose.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Signior Lopez I am come—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I know it, and for what too—come Brother, that was to have been—if you can forget what's past I shall, your Sons presents shall be restor'd, and I'll present my Cousin Biancha, whom I hear he's to marry, with two thousand Crowns for a Suit of dressing Plate.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well, I did ever think thee a good man in the worst of our Quarrels—call up my Son and the Company with him, brother, we'll keep the Name, though we are not, so may we never meet but thus, Oh!
Oh Boys! Such news, such ample Satisfaction, that his Generosity almost brings tears in my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: No Complements Signior Carlos, all is well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But here's a Gentleman I've most offended, can you forgive me Sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The joy I have to find you safe, cancels all injuries; and it shall be the future study of my Life to gain your Friendship.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And mine to shew it Sir—if I am not deceiv'd, this Gentleman was he that rescued you in that unhappy broil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do remember some such bustle Sir,
But knew not 'twas my Brother that I serv'd.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Was it thy hand Antonio, bless'd be thy Arm, and mine that press'd no deeper.

sp.speaker: Dor to Bian.
sp.p: Give you joy Couzin.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: I ha't, I hope, if Carlos can bestow it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Blessings on ye all, Brother Francisco, 'tis such a comfort to see our Children thus provided for, that sure no ordinary Joy must wait upon 'em; let's be Luxurious in this Festival, and stretch our strings to make it truly Glorious.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Stretch! By St. Jago I'll turn my baggs inside outwards, till we have purchast the utmost of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Must I be left out of this joy Sir?
What say'st thou Farmoza?
Hast not thou a grumbling towards night?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Yes, if I thought you could perform as well as your Master.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I am not so tempted Farmoza, but in the dark who knows but Joan may be as good as you know the Proverb—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Come, none shall depart from this house unsatisfied; take him Farmoza, and I'll give you 500 Crowns to begin the world with.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: I am at your worships dispose Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: And if thou canst encrease thy Family by her, I'll give thee as much more to provide for it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir, I have a good Steel and a Flint, if the Tinder will take fire.

sp.speaker: Lop.
Fran.
sp.l: And with me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Mine's the next.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: May nothing interrupt these Lovers Bliss,
But every day prove fortunate as this.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: [Spoken by Mr. Nokes, Mr. Lee, and Mr. Mountfort.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lee.
sp.l: NAY, Prithee come forward and be'nt so asham'd,
Time enough to be sad, when thou'rt sure thy Plays dam'd;

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: A Player and bashful, 'tis as senseless I'm sure,
As that Vizards should swear they come here not to Whore,

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: Or that sharpers wont pay, yet deny they are poor;
'Tis as senseless in us as in some sparks of the Nation,
Who wear Red to shun debts, and pretend 'tis a fashion,
To see 'em strut about in mean conditions,
Despising of want, and cursing Commissions.

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Ay, or that Vintners should swear, they are pleas'd with the votes
Which oblig'd 'em to sell for the future in Pots;
Why, I may as well pretend to be as wise in the City,

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: Why Brother I think in your Trade you are witty,

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Ay, but that Jest is over, the more's the pitty;
Come prithee bear up, and be not so shy,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Nay Masters I'll swear you make me blush—

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: You Lye.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Speak but for me this time, I'll desire no more;

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Well, make your Leg,

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: And begone you Son of a Whore,

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Well now Master Lee,

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: What d'say Master Nokes,

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: With what?

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Your Gibes and your Jokes;

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: Mr. Mountfort desir'd you'd speak of his Play,

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: I have been considering, and I don't know what to say;

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: Why, they know't, now they have seen't,

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Ay, and if they like't they may;
There's one thing I'm ssure, which none of you know,

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: Yes they do; that is, the Play's but so so.

sp.speaker: Nokes.
sp.l: Well, mark what I say, and remember it too,
Mr. Lee and my self—come Tony let's go.
